titleStmt.title: Again I Steam Over The
a hand-written transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: Whitman's diary from his trip to Canada in 1880. William White, in his edition of Whitman's Daybooks and Notebooks, noted a relationship between material in this notebook and the poem "The Pilot in the Mist."

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt

The verso is letterhead from the Asylum for the Insane in London.

lg.l:
again I steam over the
Saguenay's brown-black
waters

I see tThe browne-black waters,
and the thin lines streaks of white
curd, and the dazzling silver
sun-dash on the stream

TheThe banks of greeny grim mountains and the
rocks, are keep the banks

I see
The grim and savage scene

l.del:
made a grood breakfast
of sea-trout finishing
off with wild rasperriesraspberries

lg.l:
hotels here, a few fashionably
but they get away—soon
—it is partlyalmost cold
except the middles
of somea few of the July
& August days
